Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Order within disorder: Understanding the conformational landscape of intrinsically disordered proteins

Proteins bind specific partners to perform functions such as building molecular structures and transmitting molecular signals. Traditionally, proteins were understood to have a stable structure, however, research in the last twenty years has revealed that over one third of eukaryotic proteins contain long unstructured regions. Such intrinsically disordered proteins transition among an ensemble of conformations, a behavior responsible for their ability to bind multiple partners, and leading to their enrichment in cellular pathways. In certain classes of bacterial antitoxin proteins, transitions between extended and compact conformations directly control stress response pathways. Using a hybrid computational and experimental approach, the PI will determine the (1) conformational ensemble of a specific antitoxin, (2) function of each conformation, and (3) transition rates between the conformations. Mutations that modify the antitoxin?s conformational ensemble affect interaction with other macromolecules in the toxin-antitoxin regulatory network will be investigated.

This project will provide new understanding of stress response pathways in bacteria and will yield novel methods for determining transient conformations of intrinsically disordered proteins and their functions. The PI will obtain training in experimental methods and expand her computational abilities. Algorithms and results of this work will be placed on the web to facilitate and advance future research in the field. Additionally, the PI will mentor a summer high school student on a bioinformatics project examining disordered regions of antitoxin proteins.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Receiving the NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology allowed me to gain training and perform research on intrinsically disordered proteins in both a computational and an experimental lab. Because I had a purely computational background before beginning my postdoc, this cross-disciplinary training significantly enriched my understanding of biology and has made me a much stronger scientist. 

My research through this fellowship focused on intrinsically disordered antitoxin proteins within bacterial toxin-antitoxin (TA) modules. TA modules exist in nearly all free-living bacteria, where they regulate cell fate in response to various stressors. In the most-studied class of TA modules, an antitoxin protein normally inhibits its partner toxin protein. Certain stress conditions trigger a decrease in antitoxin population, freeing the toxin from inhibition. The free toxin then halts essential cellular processes, causing cell death or quiescence. These modules depend on antitoxin structural disorder to function, as disorder ensures faster degradation of antitoxins than toxins. Because of their role in controlling cell fate, TA modules have recently attracted interest as novel antibiotic targets. Indeed, bacterial infections are a leading cause of death worldwide, and the accelerated emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains is exacerbating their already devastating presence. The antibiotic discovery rate has slowed dramatically over the past few decades, and novel antibiotics are desperately needed.

I investigated the intrinsically disordered CcdA antitoxin from the CcdA-CcdB TA module in E. coli. CcdA contains an ordered region and two intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs). These IDRs have dual roles in that they (1) bind and inhibit the CcdB toxin in order to promote normal cell growth and (2) contain the major cleavage sites for degradation enzymes in order to promote cell death. Previous experimental work on CcdA indicated that the IDRs sample three distinct states, but the data were sufficient only to provide low-resolution models for two of the states and no model for the third state. I became intrigued by how these disordered IDR configurations contribute to opposing cellular outcomes: growth or death.

I therefore conducted multiple long time-scale molecular dynamics simulations of CcdA in order to compute its free energy landscape and then validated the derived conformational ensemble against distributions of low-resolution parameters obtained through biophysical experiments on CcdA. The theoretical ensemble clarified previous experimental data for CcdA by both providing atomistic detail for sampled states and quantifying relative state populations. Analysis of these states indicated that CcdA’s dominant state, in which both IDRs contact the ordered region, has reduced toxin-binding ability and is protected from degradation. In contrast, CcdA’s other two states, in which one or both IDRs extends away from the ordered region, facilitate binding to CcdB and expose CcdA to degradation. Thus, biasing CcdA’s ensemble toward a particular state would modify CcdA’s function and, thereby, influence cell fate. This work is currently under review for publication.

My wet-lab experience through this fellowship provided insight into experimental methods and caveats that I had been unaware of as a purely computational biologist. My new understanding of experiments has changed both how I read scientific literature and develop hypotheses and approaches. Furthermore, the additional years I spent in a computational lab have greatly increased my understanding of the physics and chemistry underlying biological processes. I am very grateful for the depth of training provided to me through this fellowship and my mentors.   

While studying the literature on the intrinsically disordered CcdA protein, I collected a substantial amount of information on intrinsically disordered proteins in general. This research led to two review articles on intrinsically disordered proteins – one discussing computational and experimental methods for characterizing these proteins, and another highlighting unique functions facilitated by disorder. Additionally, I developed a new method for predicting the amount of disorder in a protein based on its SAXS profile.

In addition to my own research, I mentored several students on research projects. Specifically, I worked with one MIT undergraduate and two visiting undergraduates, and these projects led to a first-author publication for one undergraduate. Outside of research, I took on a leadership role as a Community Building Co-Chair of the MIT Postdoctoral Association. As Chair, I organized monthly events in which postdocs could interact with each other, the broader MIT community, and members of the Boston/Cambridge community. I further organized a monthly evening seminar series highlighting postdoc research. At each seminar, 2-3 postdocs would present their research to an interdisciplinary group of postdocs. These talks were followed by a social hour, which encouraged knowledge exchange across disciplines. Outside of the postdoc community, I also served as a mathematics and biology judge at the Massachusetts State Science and Engineering High School Fair in 2014 and 2015. This event allowed me to share my passion for research with high school students, while serving as a role model to young girls interested in pursuing scientific careers.
